questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of chest pain. She describes the pain as intermittent and burning. She states that she has tried using proton pump inhibitors but has had no relief of her symptoms. She has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tightness of the skin of the fingers; there are small nonhealing, nonpurulent ulcers over thickened skin on the fingertips. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium. Which of the following findings is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

c-ANCA are positive in approx. 90% of patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Affected individuals usually have a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, ocular manifestations (scleritis, episcleritis, uveitis), ulcerating mucocutaneous granulomas, and/or vasculitic purpura.

B) CORRECT:

Antitopoisomerase I antibodies (anti-Scl-70) can be found in approx. 40% of individuals with diffuse SSc and indicate a poor prognosis and higher risk of severe interstitial lung disease. Further laboratory findings associated with diffuse SSc include antinuclear antibodies (approx. 90% of cases) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. See “Overview of ANAs” table.

Anticentromere antibody is the main parameter for limited SSc which may also show positive testing for anti-Scl-70.

C) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies have a very high sensitivity and specificity for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). This patient does not present with symptoms of PBC such as fatigue, generalized itching, and elevated cholestatic parameters.

D) INCORRECT:

Antihistone antibodies are characteristic for drug-induced lupus erythematosus and present in approx. 95% of cases. In this patient with symptoms of diffuse SSc, a different antibody is more likely to be found.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro/SSA and/or anti-La/SSB antibodies are found in about 70% of individuals with Sjögren syndrome. Although Sjögren syndrome may also manifest with reflux esophagitis, respiratory complications, and similar skin manifestations (secondary to Raynaud phenomenon) in a middle-aged woman, it is also characterized by xerophthalmia and xerostomia (combination thereof known as Sicca syndrome), which are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical findings of diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), including sclerodactyly (skin tightness and thickening, nonpurulent ulcers), pulmonary fibrosis (fine, inspiratory crackles), and gastroesophageal reflux disease (chest pain, weight loss) due to esophageal hypomotility.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressive fatigue and joint pain. She has a 1-year history of skin changes and a 4-month history of episodic pallor of her fingers. She reports that the skin of her face, neck, and hands is always dry and itchy; there are also numerous “red spots” on her face. She has become more “clumsy” and often drops objects. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with lansoprazole. She does not smoke. She occasionally drinks a beer or a glass of wine. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 154/98 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min. Examination shows hardening and thickening of the skin of face, neck, and hands. There are small dilated blood vessels around her mouth and on her oral mucosa. Mouth opening is reduced. Active and passive range of motion of the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints is limited. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum creatinine concentration is 1.4 mg/dL. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dental caries are a typical finding of Sjögren syndrome, which can also manifest with joint pain and Raynaud phenomenon. Although Sjögren syndrome may be secondary to other autoimmune diseases, such as SSc, this patient lacks the characteristic glandular symptoms associated with this condition: dryness of the mouth (xerostomia), eyes (xerophthalmia), and other mucosal surfaces (e.g., nose, pharynx, vagina).

B) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can manifest with arthralgia, Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasia, and increased creatinine due to renal involvement. However, the skin involvement in SLE is typically characterized by a malar rash and photosensitivity; thickening and hardening of the skin would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with SSc are at an increased risk of lung disease with more than 50% having some form of lung involvement in the course of their lifetime. The most common forms of lung involvement include interstitial lung disease (ILD) and pulmonary hypertension, which can occur separately or in combination. ILD can be seen in both types of SSc but is far more common in patients with diffuse SSc. Other complications of SSc include renal disease (with scleroderma renal crisis being the most severe form of renal involvement), cardiac disease (fibrosis, myocarditis, and pericarditis), gastrointestinal tract involvement (esophageal dysmotility and small bowel dysmotility), and thromboembolic events.

D) INCORRECT:

Urolithiasis is a common complication of gout, which can cause arthralgia and a reduced range of motion of the interphalangeal joints. However, Raynaud phenomenon, hardening and thickening of the skin, telangiectasias, and reduced mouth opening would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Dactylitis is seen in a variety of conditions such as psoriatic arthritis, sarcoidosis, and sickle-cell disease. SSc is not associated with dactylitis but instead manifests with sclerodactyly.

F) INCORRECT:

Swan neck deformity is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can also cause Raynaud phenomenon and arthritis of the fingers. However, RA typically manifests on the metacarpal and proximal interphalangeal joints, sparing the distal interphalangeal joints that are affected in this patient. In addition, dermatological manifestations of RA are limited to rheumatoid nodules; thickening and hardening of the skin would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, joint pain and reduced range of motion of her finger joints, Raynaud phenomenon, hardening and thickening of the skin, telangiectasia, and reduced mouth opening (due to perioral skin tightening), the combination of which suggests systemic sclerosis (SSc). The presence of gastroesophageal reflux disease, elevated serum creatinine, and hypertension indicates extracutaneous organ involvement.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 2-month history of chest pain and heartburn after meals. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and especially when lying down. She has a history of occasional small joint pain and Raynaud disease treated with nifedipine. There is no family history of serious illness. She emigrated to the US from Nigeria 5 years ago. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Thickening and hardening of the skin is seen on the hands and face. There are several firm, white nodules on the elbows and fingertips. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies are associated with diffuse SSc and, especially scleroderma renal crisis. However, this patient's history and symptoms suggest CREST syndrome, which is associated with lcSSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are highly specific for inflammatory myopathies like polymyositis and dermatomyositis. This patient's history and symptoms suggest CREST syndrome, a manifestation of lcSSc. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are not seen in this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

In low titers, Anti-U1 RNP antibodies are seen in several autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus). High titers are typical for mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD), which manifests with overlapping symptoms of at least two autoimmune connective tissue diseases (e.g., SSc, SLE, idiopathic inflammatory myopathies). Although this patient has CREST syndrome, a manifestation of limited SSc, no other features of MCTD (e.g., myositis, arthritis, or pulmonary hypertension) are present.

D) CORRECT:

Anticentromere antibodies are diagnostic of CREST syndrome and can be found in about half of individuals with this condition. Other typical laboratory findings include positive antinuclear antibodies, increased γ-globulins in serum protein electrophoresis, and increased inflammatory markers.

See “Overview of ANAs” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies are most commonly associated with diffuse SSc and indicate a poor prognosis. The patient's symptoms and history are suggestive of CREST syndrome, a manifestation of limited SSc. While anti-Scl-70 antibodies may also be seen in patients with CREST syndrome, another finding is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are seen in approx. 70% of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus and are highly specific for this condition. Furthermore, anti-dsDNA antibody levels correlate with the disease activity and are associated with lupus nephritis. This patient's history and symptoms suggest CREST syndrome, a manifestation of limited SSc. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are not typically present in this condition.
questions.hint: This middle-aged woman with a history of Raynaud disease presents with gastroesophageal reflux, sclerodactyly, and calcinosis cutis. These features indicate CREST syndrome, a manifestation of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (SSc).

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of bloating and constipation alternating with diarrhea. She eats a balanced diet, and there are no associations between her symptoms and specific foods. She had been a competitive swimmer since high school but stopped going to training 4 months ago because her fingers hurt and turned blue as soon as she got into the cold water. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. Physical examination shows swollen hands and fingers with wax-like thickening of the skin. There are numerous small, superficial, dilated blood vessels at the tips of the fingers. The abdomen is distended and mildly tender with no guarding or rebound. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Doughy texture of the pretibial skin
Inflammation and ulcers in the rectum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doughy pretibial skin is consistent with pretibial myxedema secondary to Graves disease. Other symptoms suggestive of Graves disease include exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, possibly with an audible bruit. While hyperthyroidism can cause diarrhea, this patient has no other features of hyperthyroidism or Graves disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral miosis could suggest opioid intoxication. While opioid use can cause constipation and withdrawal can cause diarrhea, there are no further signs to suggest opioid use, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Outpouchings of the sigmoid colon are consistent with diverticulosis. Colonic diverticulosis is often asymptomatic but can manifest with gastrointestinal bleeding and/or abdominal pain in older patients with a history of low-fiber diet and constipation. If complicated by infection, it progresses to diverticulitis, which causes additional symptoms of fever, leukocytosis, and left lower quadrant tenderness. This patient's age (< 50 years), balanced diet, and numerous extraintestinal symptoms make diverticulosis an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Villous atrophy in the small bowel is consistent with celiac disease (CD). While this patient's diarrhea and bloating may suggest CD, there is no association between her gastrointestinal symptoms and gluten-containing foods, and she exhibits no extraintestinal manifestations of malabsorption or dermatitis herpetiformis, both commonly associated with CD.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased intestinal lactase levels lead to lactose malabsorption, which may result in lactose intolerance. Although this patient has abdominal bloating and diarrhea, her symptoms are not associated with the consumption of lactose-containing milk products, nor would lactase deficiency explain the various extraintestinal symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Rectal inflammation and ulcers are consistent with ulcerative colitis (UC). Although inflammatory bowel disease can cause diarrhea, UC is classically associated with bloody diarrhea. Also, none of this patient's extraintestinal symptoms are consistent with UC, such as uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

G) INCORRECT:

Dilation of periumbilical veins, also known as caput medusae, is consistent with portal hypertension secondary to liver cirrhosis. While abdominal distention and telangiectasia are clinical features of liver cirrhosis, this patient has other cutaneous findings (Raynaud phenomenon, sclerodactyly) that are more suggestive of SSc. Furthermore, a patient with advanced liver disease would also exhibit signs of jaundice, coagulopathy, edema from hypoalbuminemia, and hyperestrogenism.

H) CORRECT:

Limited SSc, which is the most common type of SSc, typically manifests in middle-aged women with sclerosis of the fingers, hands, and face. As many patients also present with symptoms of CREST syndrome (calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia), further evaluation of this patient will likely show small white calcium deposits on the pressure points of the extremities (e.g., elbows, knees, fingertips). Though more common in diffuse SSc, internal organ involvement, in particular gastrointestinal involvement, may also occur as the disease progresses.
Image Description:

Photograph of the elbow of a patient with CREST syndrome

A multinodular yellowish-white lesion with superficial ulceration can be seen.
Small satellite nodules are visible adjacent to the main lesion.

These features are characteristic of calcinosis cutis, which most commonly occurs over the pressure points of the extremities.
questions.hint: This patient presents with Raynaud phenomenon, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, the combination of which suggests limited systemic sclerosis (SSc). Her 1-year history of bloating, constipation, and diarrhea indicates extracutaneous involvement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough for the past 6 months. He also reports fatigue and difficulty swallowing solid foods. In cold weather, his fingers often turn blue and become painful. He occasionally smokes cigarettes on weekends. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mm Hg. The skin over his trunk and arms is thickened and tightened. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally over the lower lung fields on auscultation. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient with diffuse SSc is at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Right-sided filling pressures increase as a result of pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload. An increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is thus likely to ensue.

B) INCORRECT:

Restrictive lung diseases increase the elastic recoil of lungs and impair their ability to expand, thus causing decreased lung compliance. This patient with diffuse SSc likely has restrictive lung disease and, therefore, decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

C) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is caused by collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli, which interferes with their ability to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries, resulting in decreased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity of the lungs (DLCO). Manifestations of ILD include progressive exertional dyspnea, chronic nonproductive cough, and inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Pulmonary involvement (e.g., ILD, pulmonary arterial hypertension, lung cancer) is the leading cause of death in patients with diffuse SSc.

D) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance, which is the resistance of the pulmonary tree to airflow during inspiration and expiration, is a parameter for airway obstruction and is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. As SSc causes restrictive lung disease, airway resistance is not affected.

E) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. While the A-a gradient is normal in cases of hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when ventilation-perfusion mismatch, shunting, and limited diffusion occur. This patient with signs and symptoms of diffuse SSc is at risk of pulmonary fibrosis, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.
questions.hint: The combination of pulmonary symptoms, dysphagia, Raynaud phenomenon, and sclerotic skin raises concern for diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), which frequently causes interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-day history of headache and breathlessness on exertion. During the same period, he has vomited twice and has not passed urine. He also reports pain and stiffness in his fingers that has worsened progressively over the past 2 years. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows pallor, 2+ pretibial edema, and jugular venous distention. The skin on the arms, chest, and upper back is coarse and thickened. Diffuse cutaneous hyperpigmentation and hypopigmented patches with perifollicular hypopigmentation are noted. Contractures are present in the proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over both lung bases. S1 and S2 are normal. An S3 gallop is heard at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL, and his serum creatinine concentration is 5.3 mg/dL. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticentromere antibodies are typically associated with CREST syndrome, a common manifestation of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc). LcSSc can manifest with cutaneous and articular manifestations similar to those seen in this patient. However, skin findings would be limited to the face and hands (the trunk would be spared), and SRC is rare in lcSSc. Patients also typically have a history of Raynaud syndrome and present with calcinosis cutis on physical examination.

B) CORRECT:

SRC is associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), which manifests with findings of intravascular hemolysis such as decreased serum haptoglobin, increased lactate dehydrogenase, and schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. Urinalysis may be normal or show mild proteinuria, granular casts, and microscopic hematuria. Treatment of SRC includes angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and, if necessary, renal replacement therapy. Risk factors for developing SRC include high-dose steroid therapy, presence of anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, and rapidly-progressive diffuse skin involvement.

This patient's dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and diffuse crackles on auscultation are likely due to interstitial lung disease. Peripheral edema, increased jugular venous pressure and an S3 gallop indicate right heart failure, likely caused by pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum complement concentration is seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Nearly all of the patient's extracutaneous clinical manifestations could potentially be seen in SLE because SLE can cause nonerosive arthritis, exudative pleural effusion, interstitial lung disease, heart failure (due to pericarditis, myocarditis, or Libman-Sacks endocarditis), and/or lupus nephritis. However, this patient's thickened and hardened skin, salt-and-pepper hypopigmentation, and joint contractures make SSc the more likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with SRC, a decreased rather than increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) would be expected as a result of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Increased TIBC would be seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia caused by gastrointestinal blood loss. Gastrointestinal blood loss can occur in patients with SSc due to gastric antral vascular ectasia or chronic esophagitis. However, this patient has no history of melena, heartburn, or dysphagia to suggest either of these conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-CCP antibodies are seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). All of this patient's extracutaneous clinical manifestations could potentially be explained by RA because RA can cause erosive arthritis, joint stiffness, anemia of chronic disease, pleural effusion, interstitial lung disease, heart failure (due to cardiomyopathy), and nephrotic syndrome (due to membranous nephropathy or reactive amyloidosis). However, the cutaneous manifestations of RA are subcutaneous nodules, palpable purpura, and/or pyoderma gangrenosum, rather than thickening and hardening of the skin. Moreover, acute-onset oliguria and a rapid surge in serum creatinine would not be expected because the renal failure that occurs with reactive amyloidosis or membranous nephropathy typically develops over months to years.
questions.hint: Sclerodactyly (interphalangeal joint contractures), thickening and hardening of the skin on the arms, chest, and upper back, and diffuse hyper- and hypopigmented patches with perifollicular hypopigmentation (salt-and-pepper hypopigmentation) raises concern for diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc). Scleroderma renal crisis (SRC) occurs in 10–15% of cases within a few years of the onset of dermatologic manifestations, resulting in acute-onset severe hypertension and features of acute renal failure (e.g., increased creatinine, anuria).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and difficulty swallowing for 6 weeks. She also complains of painful discoloration in her fingers when exposed to cold weather. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 4 years. She appears younger than her stated age. Physical examination shows smooth, swollen fingers with small white calcifications on her fingertips bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cirrhosis is a condition caused by chronic damage to the liver, which can result from autoimmune diseases such as primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis, not SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways. COPD is primarily caused by long-term smoking (i.e., ≥ 20–30 pack-years) and is not associated with SSc; it is an unlikely complication in this patient with a 4-pack-year smoking history.

C) CORRECT:

SSc is characterized by fibrosis, collagen deposition, and noninflammatory vasculopathy, all of which increase this patient's risk of pulmonary hypertension. Remodeling of small vessels can also result in coronary artery disease or renal crisis. In addition, lung involvement in SSc includes interstitial lung disease. This patient's limited skin involvement (face and fingers) raises suspicion for limited SSc, which is detectable through anticentromere antibodies. The more severe form, diffuse SSc, presents with anti-Scl-70, or anti-RNA-polymerase III autoantibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

GBM involvement and the development of glomerular nephritis are hallmark features of Alport syndrome and Goodpasture syndrome, not of SSc. The GBM is not affected by SSc; however, remodeling and fibrosis of renal vessels in SSc can cause renal crisis with potentially life-threatening complications (e.g., oliguric renal failure, (malignant) hypertension, encephalopathy, or microangiopathic hemolytic anemia).

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic aneurysms are a known sequela of connective tissue diseases like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, both of which are defined by hyperelastic connective tissue. In SSc, fibrosis and collagen deposits make connective tissue more rigid, increasing the risk for small vessel pathologies, such as CAD and thromboembolism.

F) INCORRECT:

Chondrocalcinosis usually presents as monoarthritis (sometimes with contractures), affecting the knees and other large joints. It is not associated with finger involvement, such as this patient's calcinosis cutis. Although both chondrocalcinosis and calcinosis cutis occur in hypercalcemia (e.g., due to hyperparathyroidism), chondrocalcinosis is not a feature of SSc.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dysphagia, Raynaud phenomenon, and has evidence of sclerodactyly and calcinosis cutis on exam. The overall presentation is concerning for systemic sclerosis (SSc).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss and difficulty swallowing. She is able to swallow liquids without difficulty but feels like solid foods get stuck in her throat. Physical examination shows taut skin and limited range of motion of the fingers. There are telangiectasias over the cheeks. An esophageal motility study shows absence of peristalsis in the lower two-thirds of the esophagus and decreased lower esophageal sphincter pressure. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Spongiosis and hyperkeratosis of the epidermis
Budding yeasts on the oral mucosa
Arteriolar wall thickening in the kidney

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyloid deposits in the liver would be consistent with systemic amyloidosis, which can also cause dysphagia if there is esophageal involvement. Amyloidosis has a wide spectrum of clinical presentations depending on the organ systems affected, but the most common findings include macroglossia, nephrotic syndrome, and cardiac arrhythmia. Impaired peristalsis on esophageal manometry, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias are not typical features of systemic amyloidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidermal spongiosis with hyperkeratosis is a histologic finding observed in atopic dermatitis, which is associated with eosinophilic esophagitis. Although eosinophilic esophagitis can also cause dysphagia, it is inconsistent with this woman's reduced peristalsis on esophageal manometry, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. Moreover, she lacks a history of atopic disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Budding yeasts on the oral mucosa would be consistent with mucocutaneous Candida albicans infection, which can also cause candida esophagitis in immunocompromised states. Candida esophagitis typically presents with retrosternal pain, odynophagia, and/or dysphagia. This patient does not complain of odynophagia and has esophageal manometry findings demonstrating decreased lower esophageal sphincter pressures, making candida esophagitis unlikely.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

Multiple confluent, white-gray plaques in a longitudinal pattern are visible.

These findings are characteristic of Candida esophagitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma cruzi nests in the myocardium is a histologic finding associated with Chagas disease. Gastrointestinal manifestations of Chagas disease include megaesophagus and achalasia, which can also cause dysphagia. In contrast to this patient, achalasia is characterized by increased lower esophageal sphincter pressures.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

E) INCORRECT:

Microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells on peripheral blood smear would suggest iron deficiency anemia, as seen in Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Although Plummer-Vinson syndrome can also cause dysphagia (due to formation of esophageal webs), other classic symptoms such as atrophic glossitis, angular cheilitis, odynophagia, and weakness are not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A thin, semilunar membrane (esophageal web; blue overlay) projects into the esophageal lumen. Esophageal webs usually occur in the upper esophagus and do not involve the muscle layer.

Cervical esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia form the classic triad of findings in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

F) CORRECT:

Renal vascular involvement is common in patients with SSc. Thickening of the renal arteriolar wall due to abnormal collagen deposition leads to narrowing of the arteriolar lumen, which results in decreased renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate. In 10-15% of patients with diffuse SSc, this progresses to scleroderma renal crisis.

Patients with esophageal dysmotility are at increased risk for Barrett esophagus and esophageal strictures secondary to chronic gastroesophageal reflux.
questions.hint: Esophageal dysmotility (dysphagia, absent peristalsis), sclerodactyly (taut skin, limited range of motion of fingers), and telangiectasias are characteristic of systemic sclerosis (SSc). Esophageal dysmotility in SSc results from atrophy and fibrosis of the esophageal smooth muscles.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty swallowing for the past 1 year. She was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux 3 years ago and takes pantoprazole. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. Examination shows hardening of the skin of the fingers and several white papules on the fingertips. There are small dilated blood vessels on the face. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's difficulty swallowing?

choices.text: Degeneration of neurons within esophageal wall
Outpouching of the lower pharyngeal mucosa
Demyelination of brain and spinal cord axons
Pathologic inclusions within both upper and lower motor neurons

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atrophy and fibrosis of the esophageal smooth muscles, which leads to esophageal dysmotility with gastroesophageal reflux and dysphagia, is a feature of CREST syndrome. The syndrome is a manifestation of systemic sclerosis. CREST is an acronym for the cardinal features of the condition: calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of neurons within the esophageal wall describes achalasia, a rare condition that most commonly occurs in middle-aged individuals. Patients with achalasia present with dysphagia, regurgitation, retrosternal pain and cramps, and weight loss. This patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

Smooth funnel-shaped tapering (green overlay) in the region of the lower esophageal sphincter is accompanied by a widening (double-headed arrow) of the prestenotic distal esophagus (red overlay).

The appearance of the esophagus in achalasia is referred to as “bird-beak sign” (illustration). If the contour of the narrowed region is irregular and/or involves more than just the distal esophagus, the alternative diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma must be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Premature contractions of the distal esophagus suggest esophageal spasm. Although this condition may also cause dysphagia and retrosternal discomfort (or even severe chest pain) during meals, this patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

Helical contractions of the lower esophagus (green overlay), resulting in a corkscrew-like appearance.

Seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

D) INCORRECT:

Outpouching of the lower pharyngeal mucosa is known as Zenker diverticulum, which typically occurs in middle-aged or older patients and can present with dysphagia as well as regurgitation. However, the patient would also complain of aspiration of foul-smelling undigested food, and the cutaneous findings seen here would not be expected.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

The contrast-enhanced mass in the upper esophagus is most likely a Zenker diverticulum.

E) INCORRECT:

Demyelination of brain and spinal cord axons is characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). Dysphagia can arise if the cranial nerves IX and X are involved. However, this patient has no other signs of MS, e.g., optic neuritis. Although MS can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the localization of CNS lesions, this patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.

F) INCORRECT:

Pathologic inclusions within both the upper and lower motor neurons suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which can result in dysphagia from bulbar atrophy. However, only a small proportion of patients initially present with bulbar palsy without further upper motor neuron signs and lower motor neuron signs. Furthermore, this patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

G) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic cells with adjacent Barrett mucosa indicate adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. While early stages of esophageal cancer are generally asymptomatic, patients present with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and retrosternal chest or back pain as well as anemia due to chronic blood loss in late stages of the disease. Gastroesophageal reflux and smoking are major risk factors, although cancer is unlikely to arise within 3 years of onset of GERD. This patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.

H) INCORRECT:

Tissue membrane obstructing the esophageal lumen describes an esophageal web. It usually occurs in association with Plummer-Vinson syndrome and can cause dysphagia, which is seen in this patient. This patient's cutaneous findings suggest a different underlying etiology.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A thin, semilunar membrane (esophageal web; blue overlay) projects into the esophageal lumen. Esophageal webs usually occur in the upper esophagus and do not involve the muscle layer.

Cervical esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia form the classic triad of findings in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.
questions.hint: The combination of calcinosis cutis, dysphagia, GERD, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias suggests CREST syndrome.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her wife because of a sudden onset of headache and nausea 2 hours ago. She developed pronounced fatigue and dark-colored urine 4 days ago. The patient has a 1-year history of diffuse pain in her muscles, wrists, and elbows, as well as thickening of the skin on her hands and fingers, which she attributes to her work as a warehouse associate. She takes ibuprofen for the pain but it provides minimal relief. Her family history is unknown. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 159/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an area of diffuse hypopigmentation on her upper back and posterior arms that spares the perifollicular regions. The skin on her hands and fingers feels stiff. Joint examination shows tender contractures in her wrists and elbows. Neurologic examination shows no focal signs. Her neck is supple with a normal range of motion. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
23%


Leukocyte count
9000/mm3



Platelet count
185,000/mm3



Lactate dehydrogenase
290 U/L


Haptoglobin

25 mg/dL (N = 41–165)


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
42 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.0 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.8 mg/dL


 Antinuclear antibodies

positive


Urine



 Blood
3+


 Protein
1+


 RBC

10–13/hpf


 Casts
none


A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenoxybenzamine is typically used for the preoperative management of patients with pheochromocytoma, which can manifest with new-onset hypertension accompanied by headache and nausea. Furthermore, pheochromocytoma can be associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF type 1), which can manifest with skin depigmentation. However, patients with NF type 1 typically develop hyperpigmented macules of patches (café au lait spots), rather than diffuse (salt-and-pepper) hypopigmentation. Moreover, pheochromocytoma is typically associated with diaphoresis, palpitations, and pallor, none of which are seen here. This patient's presentation is consistent with SRC, for which phenoxybenzamine is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is indicated for the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can manifest with fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, skin lesions, hypertension, renal dysfunction, hemolytic anemia, and positive ANA. However, individuals with SLE typically develop a maculopapular rash (most commonly butterfly rash), rather than diffuse hypopigmentation or sclerodactyly, and present with mild nondeforming arthritis, rather than tender joint contractures. This patient most likely has SRC, for which hydroxychloroquine is not typically indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Antihypertensive therapy is the most appropriate initial approach for patients with scleroderma renal crisis (SRC) because blood pressure control stabilizes and improves renal function. SRC can rapidly progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), so therapy should be initiated as soon as possible. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) are the first-line therapy given their antihypertensive efficacy and nephroprotective effects. Captopril is the most commonly used ACEI because it has a rapid onset and short duration of action, which allows for rapid dose titration. Serum creatinine should be monitored and captopril therapy should be continued despite an initial increase in serum creatinine, which is expected and typically transient. Given their associated increase in survival, long-acting ACEIs (e.g., ramipril, enalapril) should be continued indefinitely in patients who have developed SRC, regardless of their blood pressure values. Patients who develop ESRD despite ACEI therapy may require temporary or permanent renal replacement therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids can be used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can manifest with fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, joint deformities, anemia, and positive ANA. However, hypertension, sclerodactyly, diffuse skin hypopigmentation, and renal failure are not characteristic of RA. This patient most likely has SSc and SRC and should therefore avoid glucocorticoids, which can worsen renal dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine may be indicated for the management of psoriasis with psoriatic arthritis, which can manifest with skin lesions, arthralgia, and joint deformities. However, patients with psoriasis typically develop silver-white scaling with pruritus rather than diffuse hypopigmentation and present with nail involvement (e.g., nail pitting, onycholysis) and dactylitis, rather than sclerodactyly. Moreover, although patients with psoriasis can also develop hypertension and kidney disease, these complications have a chronic rather than an acute onset. Finally, hemolytic anemia and positive ANA are not characteristic of psoriasis. This patient most likely has SRC and should therefore avoid cyclosporine, which has nephrotoxic effects.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sclerodactyly, stiffness and tender joint contractures, myalgia, salt-and-pepper hypopigmentation of the skin, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), all of which are consistent with systemic sclerosis (SSc). New-onset hypertension, renal failure, and hemolytic anemia in a patient with SSc indicate scleroderma renal crisis (SRC).

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with a history of systemic sclerosis presents to the emergency department reporting headaches, decreased urine output, and elevated blood pressure readings on her home blood-pressure monitoring unit.
Her blood pressure in the emergency department is 186/78 mm Hg. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, and granular casts. Her serum creatinine level last month was 0.9 mg/dL; today, it is 3.6 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1).
Treatment with a medication from which one of the following drug classes is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and diuretics do not clearly improve prognosis among patients with scleroderma renal crisis.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and diuretics do not clearly improve prognosis among patients with scleroderma renal crisis.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and diuretics do not clearly improve prognosis among patients with scleroderma renal crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, calcium-channel blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and diuretics do not clearly improve prognosis among patients with scleroderma renal crisis.

E) CORRECT:

Scleroderma renal crisis, a potentially devastating complication of systemic sclerosis, is defined as the new onset of accelerated arterial hypertension or rapidly progressive oliguric kidney failure during the course of systemic sclerosis. Nonmalignant hypertension alone, without azotemia, is not renal crisis. Renal crisis occurs in approximately 10% of patients who have scleroderma. Before angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors were available, more than 90% of these patients developed end-stage kidney disease.

An angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor must be given acutely, even in the setting of acute kidney failure, in an attempt to salvage renal function. This class of drugs can be life-saving during scleroderma renal crisis, even in the absence of hypertension, potentially reversing the process if given sufficiently early.

Key learning point: Scleroderma renal crisis is optimally treated with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for evaluation of progressive dyspnea on exertion. She is typically healthy, other than moderate gastroesophageal reflux. She states that she has no cough or chest pain. She gives a history of her fingers turning white and painful when being exposed to cold.
Her heart rate is 103 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. At rest, her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air, but it falls to 89% with ambulation. Cardiac examination is notable for a fixed split second heart sound; she has mild, symmetric lower-extremity swelling. She has no wheezes or crackles. Her skin examination is notable for a few digital ulcers and thickened patches of skin over her hands and on the face, but not elsewhere.
A chest radiograph is without opacities, but the hila look prominent. A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits. Anticentromere antibodies are positive.
Which one of the following next steps is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s dyspnea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A methacholine challenge is used to diagnose asthma, which is unlikely in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventilation-perfusion imaging is often used in the workup after pulmonary hypertension has been confirmed, specifically to identify chronic thromboembolic disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has limited systemic sclerosis (SSc, scleroderma), given her history of esophageal disease (gastroesophageal reflux), severe Raynaud phenomenon (with digital ulcerations), and sclerodactyly. These features, along with telangiectasia and calcinosis cutis, make up the CREST features classically seen in patients with the limited variant of SSc. These patients also tend to have positive anti-centromere antibodies.

All variants of SSc are associated with the development of interstitial lung disease (ILD) as well as pulmonary arterial hypertension, but the severity of these complications typically segregates with the subtype of SSc. Limited SSc is more commonly associated with symptomatic pulmonary arterial hypertension and mild, subclinical ILD. Patients with the diffuse variant of SSc have more extensive skin involvement beyond the distal extremities and face. They are more likely to experience organ fibrosis, including severe ILD. In these patients, pulmonary arterial hypertension tends to be less severe except in the end-stages of advanced ILD.

In this patient, the presence of features of limited, rather than diffuse, SSc on physical examination makes pulmonary hypertension a more likely cause of dyspnea than interstitial fibrosis. Other features of her presentation also make pulmonary hypertension likely including ambulatory desaturation, lower-extremity edema, and a fixed split second heart sound. A chest radiograph without opacities and the absence of crackles on pulmonary auscultation make an underlying interstitial process less likely.

Echocardiography is the modality of choice during initial evaluation for pulmonary hypertension because it is noninvasive and easily obtained. Echocardiography can assess right and left ventricular function as well as systolic pulmonary artery pressure. If systolic pulmonary artery pressure is elevated, it suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, but this is not a definitive study. The next step would be a right heart catheterization, which allows the measurement of a mean pulmonary artery pressure. The diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension is made when the mean pulmonary artery pressure exceeds 20 mm Hg.

Key learning point: The best initial study to evaluate for scleroderma-related pulmonary hypertension is an echocardiogram.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct laryngoscopy would be used to evaluate suspected vocal-cord dysfunction, which is unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT of the chest would be useful in identifying interstitial lung disease, which is less likely to explain this patient’s dyspnea. She has primarily limited systemic sclerosis with CREST features, and anti-centromere antibody.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with scleroderma undergoes evaluation for dysphagia to liquids and solids. A recent upper endoscopy revealed features consistent with reflux esophagitis; her omeprazole dose was subsequently increased.
An esophageal-motility study shows reduced peristalsis in the lower two-thirds of the esophagus and diminished pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Placement of a percutaneous gastrostomy tube
Botulinum toxin injection into the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a percutaneous gastrostomy tube is not an appropriate part of initial management for scleroderma of the esophagus, because it does not prevent gastroesophageal reflux or aspiration.

B) CORRECT:

Up to 90% of patients with systemic sclerosis develop gastrointestinal problems, most often of the esophagus. Systemic sclerosis leads to smooth-muscle atrophy and fibrosis of the distal esophagus. On esophageal manometry, this condition manifests as diminished peristalsis in the lower two-thirds of the esophagus and, with advanced disease, decreased pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter. Typical symptoms of scleroderma of the esophagus include heartburn, dysphagia, and regurgitation. The dysphagia is usually related to dysmotility, although stricture formation can occur.

Patients with scleroderma of the esophagus can benefit from lifestyle modifications (e.g., eating multiple small meals throughout the day) and medical treatment. Antisecretory therapy with a proton pump inhibitor can help relieve symptoms. In the presence of an esophageal motility disorder, the addition of metoclopramide or domperidone can also be tried to help relieve symptoms. However, both of these prokinetic agents have serious adverse effects and limitations:

• Metoclopramide can cause irreversible tardive dyskinesia, especially at higher doses and with prolonged use; hence, current recommendations are for no more than 12 weeks of therapy.
• Domperidone, which is available internationally but only available in the United States via an application process through the Food and Drug Administration, also comes with concerns for long-QT syndrome and should be used cautiously.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management approach for scleroderma of the esophagus includes both an antisecretory medication and a prokinetic agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical management for gastroesophageal reflux (Nissen fundoplication) is generally avoided because it can worsen dysphagia in the setting of dysmotility.

D) INCORRECT:

A calcium-channel blocker, such as nifedipine, may be used to treat diffuse esophageal spasm, but the drug can reduce pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter and worsen reflux symptoms in patients with systemic sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection into the lower esophageal sphincter is used to treat achalasia, which is characterized by increased pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter. The dysmotility in patients with systemic sclerosis is caused by muscle atrophy; thus, botulinum toxin is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents for follow-up 3 months after being diagnosed with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis on the basis of Raynaud phenomenon, skin thickening and tightening (sclerodactyly) of her hands and feet, a positive anticentromere antibody test, and esophageal dysmotility.
At today’s visit, she notes that her Raynaud phenomenon has worsened significantly, particularly in cold weather. She is having frequent painful episodes involving all digits of her right hand and the third digit of her left hand. She has been avoiding caffeine, has quit cigarette smoking, and is keeping warm when outside by wearing mittens, hats, and layers.
On examination, her vital signs are unremarkable. All of the digits on the right hand and the third digit on her left hand are pale and tender distal to the proximal interphalangeal joints (figure). She has no ulcers on the fingertips and has 2+ radial pulses bilaterally. Tight sclerotic skin distal to her wrists and ankles is evident bilaterally. During the course of the visit, her fingertips begin to return to their normal color.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) nor hydrochlorothiazide are indicated for treating Raynaud phenomenon.

B) INCORRECT:

A phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, such as sildenafil, would be an appropriate pharmacologic treatment to try if calcium-channel blockers are ineffective, but sildenafil is not considered first-line therapy, in part because of its high cost.

C) INCORRECT:

Although angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, such as ramipril, are an important treatment for scleroderma renal crisis, the evidence for effectiveness in Raynaud phenomenon is weaker.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) nor hydrochlorothiazide are indicated for treating Raynaud phenomenon.

E) CORRECT:

A dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for symptomatic Raynaud phenomenon in patients for whom supportive measures (for example, wearing mittens and avoiding caffeine) are no longer adequate. The medications used most commonly include nifedipine (extended-release formulation) and amlodipine.

Key learning point: In patients with systemic sclerosis who have symptomatic Raynaud phenomenon despite supportive measures, the first-line pharmacologic treatment for the Raynaud phenomenon is a calcium-channel blocker, such as nifedipine or amlodipine.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents at a follow-up visit for limited systemic sclerosis, which was diagnosed 3 years ago. A previous serologic workup was notable for a positive anticentromere antibody result. The patient takes maximum-dose nifedipine for Raynaud phenomenon. She now complains, for the first time, of increased shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance.
Her physical examination is notable for cachexia, scattered telangiectasia, and skin tightness involving the fingers and face. She has acrocyanosis of the digits and evidence of old (healed) digital ulcerations in several fingers. Her cardiac examination reveals a loud second heart sound and a right ventricular heave. The lungs sound clear on bilateral auscultation. Echocardiography was attempted but nondiagnostic for technical reasons.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with a bronchodilator and a high-dose glucocorticoid
Refer the patient for lung-transplant evaluation
Refer the patient for right heart catheterization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are not thought to be effective in treating pulmonary arterial hypertension. In addition, treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids should be avoided in patients with systemic sclerosis, as it may precipitate scleroderma renal crisis, particularly in patients with rapidly progressive cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is a treatment option for interstitial lung disease, with clinical trials showing a modest benefit, but there is no strong evidence for its effectiveness in pulmonary arterial hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, which can be used to treat Raynaud phenomenon, is ineffective for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension in the vast majority of patients with systemic sclerosis. In this particular case, the patient is symptomatic despite already being on a maximum dose of nifedipine.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung transplantation is reserved for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension who have failed to respond to medical therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance in a patient with systemic sclerosis suggests pulmonary involvement. All patients with systemic sclerosis should be screened for interstitial lung disease (ILD) and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Physical examination findings of a loud second (S2) heart sound and right ventricular heave are more consistent with PAH. Also, patients with limited systemic sclerosis and a positive anticentromere antibody result are more likely to develop PAH than ILD.

Patients with suspected PAH should be referred to a pulmonary hypertension specialist or clinic for right heart catheterization to confirm the diagnosis. Vasoreactivity testing during the procedure may assist with treatment selection. Reactivity testing is performed during right heart catheterization and assesses the response of the pulmonary arterial pressure (PAP) to inhaled nitric oxide or another vasodilator; a positive response is defined as a reduction in mean PAP of ≥10 mm Hg to reach an absolute value of ≤40 mm Hg, with increased or unchanged cardiac output. If there is a positive response, then the patient may respond favorably to high-dose oral calcium-channel blockers, which are less expensive and better tolerated than alternative therapies.

If the vasoreactivity test is negative, or if high-dose calcium-channel blockers are ineffective, then alternative treatments such as prostacyclin pathway agonists, endothelin receptor antagonists, or phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors can be considered. This particular patient, who has PAH associated with connective tissue disease, has a low probability of having a positive vasoreactivity test. Some experts may therefore choose to omit this step and proceed directly to more advanced therapies.

Key learning point: Patients with systemic sclerosis are at increased risk for pulmonary complications of interstitial lung disease and pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dyspnea that started a few months ago and has worsened. She can no longer walk more than two blocks without becoming short of breath. For the past year, she has noted changes in her skin, starting in her hands but progressing to her legs, chest, and face. She feels her skin is tightening, and she reports difficulty opening and closing her hands and mouth. She also says that her fingers lose their color in cold weather.
The patient’s physical examination reveals a BMI of 25, a blood pressure of 108/92 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while she is breathing ambient air, but it drops to 84% when she walks to the bathroom. Her skin is markedly thickened and tethered from her fingertips to her wrists and moderately thickened proximally to the elbows and around her mouth, with a mildly reduced oral aperture.
Her cardiac examination is normal, but her lung examination reveals faint rales heard throughout both lung fields. She has no evidence of lower-extremity edema. A portable chest radiograph is unremarkable, and an electrocardiogram is normal.
Laboratory testing documents an antinuclear antibody titer of 1:10,240, nucleolar pattern. Other blood tests include a normal D-dimer level and negative tests for anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-Smith antibodies, but a positive test for anti-Scl-70 antibodies.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s shortness of breath?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism are each reasonable choices for a patient with new-onset dyspnea, but a patient with chronic shortness of breath and diffuse systemic scleroderma is more likely to have interstitial lung disease. The lung images achieved with CT pulmonary angiography are inferior to those achieved with a high-resolution CT directed to the lung parenchyma.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis are at high risk for interstitial lung disease, particularly those with anti-Scl-70 antibodies. High-resolution CT of the chest is more sensitive than a chest radiograph for detecting early changes of interstitial lung disease. High-resolution CT of the chest is appropriate for patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis at the time of scleroderma diagnosis, as well as for patients who have new symptoms of dyspnea or worsening lung volume measurements on pulmonary function testing.

Key learning point: The pulmonary process that frequently leads to dyspnea in a patient with diffuse systemic sclerosis is interstitial lung disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Right heart catheterization is the study of choice to confirm the presence of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension is more commonly a complication of limited, rather than diffuse, systemic sclerosis and is therefore less likely than interstitial lung disease in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography is the most appropriate study to assess for valvular vegetations in patients with suspected endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism are each reasonable choices for a patient with new-onset dyspnea, but a patient with chronic shortness of breath and diffuse systemic scleroderma is more likely to have interstitial lung disease. The lung images achieved with CT pulmonary angiography are inferior to those achieved with a high-resolution CT directed to the lung parenchyma.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman with a history of Raynaud phenomenon presents to the emergency department with severe headache, blurred vision, and confusion. She reports fatigue, arthralgias, and tightness and thickening of the skin on the arms and legs during the past 3 months.
Her blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 90 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals tightness of the skin on her fingers. Funduscopic examination shows arteriovenous nicking and flame-shaped hemorrhages. She is admitted to the intensive care unit.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
140
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.5
3.5–5.0


Urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
58
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.5
0.6–1.1


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.0
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5500
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
80,000
150,000–350,000


The result of an antinuclear antibody test is positive, with a speckled pattern. Multiple schistocytes are present in a peripheral-blood smear. Urinalysis shows 1+ proteinuria, no blood, no cells, and no casts.
Which one of the following antihypertensive agents is most appropriate for managing this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers, such as nicardipine, may improve symptoms associated with Raynaud phenomena and would be a good adjunct to an ACE inhibitor if additional agents are needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, such as esmolol, are usually avoided in patients with scleroderma and Raynaud phenomenon because these agents may lead to digital ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Little has been published on diuretics (e.g., furosemide) in this setting, but they may be useful to control the serum potassium level in patients on an ACE inhibitor.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with hypertensive emergency and historical and physical findings of scleroderma has scleroderma renal crisis (SRC). Multiple nonrandomized, uncontrolled retrospective, and prospective studies have shown that the use of angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are associated with increased antihypertensive efficacy, increased preservation of kidney function, increased incidence of renal recovery with discontinuation of dialysis, and improved survival of patients with SRC (one-year survival rate, 76% vs. 18% without an ACE inhibitor).

Common features of SRC include malignant arterial hypertension, accelerated kidney failure, and markedly increased levels of plasma renin activity; hence, ACE inhibitors are mechanistically advantageous. Captopril may be particularly beneficial because of its rapid onset, and this agent has been used more than other ACE inhibitors in patients with SRC. ACE inhibitors may be used even in the setting of reduced kidney function and can be continued if the subsequent rise in serum creatinine level is modest.

Key learning point: To control blood pressure and improve long-term outcomes in a patient with scleroderma renal crisis, the initial choice of antihypertensive drug class is an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroprusside can be added to captopril for additional control, but nitroprusside should be discontinued as soon as possible because reduced kidney function may lead to accumulation of its toxic metabolite, thiocyanate.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman reports shortness of breath and a one-year history of intermittent hand and finger swelling, color change of digits in response to cold, and progressive skin tightening on the dorsal surface of her fingers, hands, arms, face, chest, and abdomen.
On examination, she has bound-down skin extending from her fingers to both upper arms (figure); there is also distal fingertip tapering with proximal nail-fold telangiectasias and digital ulceration. The skin on her chest, breasts, abdomen, and face is thickened, and her chest has dyspigmentation with a salt-and-pepper appearance.
Pulmonary function tests reveal a reduced diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide and reduced forced vital capacity.
Echocardiography demonstrates increased myocardial thickness, depressed systolic function with a 30% left ventricular ejection fraction, and normal estimation of pulmonary arterial systolic blood pressure.
Which one of the following autoantibodies offers the most prognostic information for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody is associated with renal disease in systemic lupus erythematosus.

B) CORRECT:

Given this patient’s characteristic skin findings and internal organ involvement, she most likely has systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), a multisystem disease that is subdivided into limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis and diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis based on clinical manifestations. Both subtypes can have pulmonary involvement. Pulmonary hypertension is the most common cause of death in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, whereas interstitial lung disease is most common in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. This patient’s results on pulmonary function testing suggest the presence of interstitial lung disease.

Anti-Scl-70 (topoisomerase I) antibody is associated with an increased risk for diffuse systemic sclerosis, interstitial lung disease, cardiac fibrosis, and a poorer prognosis.

Serologic antibodies (anti-Scl-70 and anticentromere) are helpful to confirm the diagnosis of systemic sclerosis, but their absence does not exclude the condition, given the low sensitivity of these tests. Thus, all patients who meet the clinical criteria for systemic sclerosis should be screened for internal organ involvement (lung, kidney, heart, esophagus).

Key learning point: In systemic sclerosis, the presence of anti-Scl-70 (topoisomerase I) antibody is associated with increased risk of fibrotic disease of the heart and lungs as well as a poorer prognosis overall.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticentromere antibody is associated with pulmonary artery hypertension in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome). Of note, anti-Scl-70 and anticentromere antibodies occur in a mutually exclusive fashion.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-histidyl-tRNA synthetase antibody may be associated with interstitial lung disease in dermatomyositis but not in systemic sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro antibody positivity is not associated with systemic sclerosis. It is associated with Sjögren syndrome, subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-year history of progressive fatigue and joint pain. She has a 1-year history of skin changes and a 4-month history of episodic pallor of her fingers. She has become more “clumsy” and often drops objects. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 154/98 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min. Examination shows hardening and thickening of the skin of face, neck, and hands. There are small dilated blood vessels around her mouth and on her oral mucosa. Mouth opening is reduced. Active and passive range of motion of the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints is limited. Her serum creatinine concentration is 1.4 mg/dL. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dental caries are a typical finding of Sjögren syndrome, which can also manifest with joint pain and Raynaud phenomenon. Although Sjögren syndrome may be secondary to other autoimmune diseases, such as SSc, this patient lacks the characteristic glandular symptoms associated with this condition: dryness of the mouth (xerostomia), eyes (xerophthalmia), and other mucosal surfaces (e.g., nose, pharynx, vagina).

B) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can manifest with arthralgia, Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasia, and increased creatinine due to renal involvement. However, the skin involvement in SLE is typically characterized by a malar rash and photosensitivity; thickening and hardening of the skin would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with SSc are at an increased risk of lung disease with more than 50% having some form of lung involvement in the course of their lifetime. The most common forms of lung involvement include interstitial lung disease (ILD) and pulmonary hypertension, which can occur separately or in combination. ILD can be seen in both types of SSc but is far more common in patients with diffuse SSc. Other complications of SSc include renal disease (with scleroderma renal crisis being the most severe form of renal involvement), cardiac disease (fibrosis, myocarditis, and pericarditis), gastrointestinal tract involvement (esophageal dysmotility and small bowel dysmotility), and thromboembolic events.

D) INCORRECT:

Urolithiasis is a common complication of gout, which can cause arthralgia and a reduced range of motion of the interphalangeal joints. However, Raynaud phenomenon, hardening and thickening of the skin, telangiectasias, and reduced mouth opening would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Dactylitis is seen in a variety of conditions such as psoriatic arthritis, sarcoidosis, and sickle-cell disease. SSc is not associated with dactylitis but instead manifests with sclerodactyly.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, joint pain and reduced range of motion of her finger joints, Raynaud phenomenon, hardening and thickening of the skin, telangiectasia, and reduced mouth opening (due to perioral skin tightening), the combination of which suggests systemic sclerosis (SSc). The presence of gastroesophageal reflux disease, elevated serum creatinine, and hypertension indicates extracutaneous organ involvement.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of worsening fatigue, headaches, and shortness of breath to the clinic. She has a 5-year history of systemic sclerosis. Over the last month, her blood pressure has increased from 120/80 mm Hg to 180/110 mm Hg. She denies any recent medication changes or over-the-counter remedies. Examination reveals a new fourth heart sound and multiple fingertip ulcers. She is anxious about her sudden decline in health (see lab results).

Blood pressure
180/110 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
220 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Protein
Present
Absent


 Erythrocytes
Occasional
0 - 2 per high power field



What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plasma exchange therapy is used for conditions with circulating pathogenic factors, such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. The patient's presentation, with severe hypertension and renal impairment, aligns with scleroderma renal crisis, which involves vascular injury and renin-angiotensin system activation, not a process amenable to plasma exchange.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous nitroprusside is a vasodilator used in hypertensive emergencies to rapidly lower blood pressure. However, it does not address the renin-angiotensin system activation central to scleroderma renal crisis. Additionally, nitroprusside carries risks of precipitous blood pressure drops and toxicity, without altering the underlying disease process.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used for inflammatory conditions but are not effective in scleroderma renal crisis, which is driven by vascular injury and renin-angiotensin system activation. Corticosteroids can exacerbate renal crisis in systemic sclerosis, making them inappropriate for this condition.

D) CORRECT:

The sudden onset of severe hypertension, elevated creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria in a patient with systemic sclerosis suggests scleroderma renal crisis. This condition involves renal ischemia and activation of the renin-angiotensin system. Oral angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are the first-line treatment as they block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, reducing vasoconstriction and intraglomerular pressure. Initiating ACE inhibitors promptly can stabilize renal function and improve survival in scleroderma renal crisis.

Key learning point: In scleroderma renal crisis, characterized by acute kidney injury and hypertension, the use of an ACE inhibitor like lisinopril is crucial for managing blood pressure and protecting renal function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough. He also reports fatigue and difficulty swallowing solid foods. He notes that his fingers often turn blue and become painful in cold weather. He occasionally smokes cigarettes on weekends. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mm Hg. On examination, the skin over his trunk and arms is thickened and tightened. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally over the lower lung fields. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is caused by collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli, which interferes with their ability to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries, resulting in decreased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity of the lungs (DLCO). Manifestations of ILD include progressive exertional dyspnea, chronic nonproductive cough, and inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Pulmonary involvement (e.g., ILD, pulmonary arterial hypertension, lung cancer) is the leading cause of death in patients with diffuse SSc.

Key learning point: Diffuse systemic sclerosis commonly causes interstitial lung disease, leading to decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) due to collagen deposition in the alveolar walls.

B) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance, which is the resistance of the pulmonary tree to airflow during inspiration and expiration, is a parameter for airway obstruction and is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. As SSc causes restrictive lung disease, airway resistance is not affected.

C) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. While the A-a gradient is normal in cases of hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when ventilation-perfusion mismatch, shunting, and limited diffusion occur. This patient with signs and symptoms of diffuse SSc is at risk of pulmonary fibrosis, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.

D) INCORRECT:

Restrictive lung diseases increase the elastic recoil of lungs and impair their ability to expand, thus causing decreased lung compliance. This patient with diffuse SSc likely has restrictive lung disease and, therefore, decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient with diffuse SSc is at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Right-sided filling pressures increase as a result of pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload. An increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is thus likely to ensue.
questions.hint: The combination of pulmonary symptoms, dysphagia, Raynaud phenomenon, and sclerotic skin raises concern for diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), which frequently causes interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with diffuse systemic sclerosis presents with a 3-day history of nausea, fatigue, and decreased urine output. Her home blood pressure readings have increased from her usual 120/80 mm Hg to 165/95 mm Hg over the past week. Laboratory studies show creatinine 2.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL), hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL with schistocytes on peripheral smear, and platelet count 95,000/μL. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clonidine can be used as combination therapy in scleroderma renal crisis but is not the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – An ACE inhibitor is the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention for scleroderma renal crisis, which is characterized by acute hypertension, oliguric acute kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Losartan can be used as combination therapy in scleroderma renal crisis but is not the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine can be used as combination therapy in scleroderma renal crisis but is not the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxazosin can be used as combination therapy in scleroderma renal crisis but is not the most appropriate initial pharmacological intervention.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of diffuse systemic sclerosis presents to the emergency with a 2-day history of mild headache and decreased urine output. She reports worsening dysphagia and reflux symptoms over the past month despite proton pump inhibitor therapy. Vital signs are BP, 170/105; P, 98; R, 18; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination shows no peripheral edema. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, platelets 95,000/μL, elevated LDH, creatinine 3.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL), BUN 52 mg/dL, and 2+ proteinuria on urinalysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation is consistent with scleroderma renal crisis (SRC). ACE inhibitors are the mainstay of therapy for SRC. Blood pressure should be titrated to achieve approximately 10% reduction per day until normotensive.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers should be avoided in patients with systemic sclerosis as they can cause vasospasm and may worsen Raynaud phenomenon and digital ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not the appropriate first-line intervention for a patient with systemic sclerosis presenting with acute hypertension and kidney injury.

D) INCORRECT:
